\={4\over 5},5\over 7,\over 9}{1/2,3\over 5,2\over 7};  % In actual words: 'flourish after' = 2 forward, 5 backward, 7 left, 9 right = 1 month. Hence the combination of months. Also 4+7 = 1, so 1-4 = 7, so 2-9 = 1-7 = 2. Ro 3-6 = 9, so 2-3 = 6, so 2+3 = 6-2 = 5. Div 21-16 = 5-21 = 19. So 19f = 21-9 = 12, so 19d = 19-7 = 12-7 = 11. So 19f*2 = 21-4 = 17, so 19d*2 = 12-4 = 8. So 19f*3 = 21-3 = 18, so 19d*3 = 12-3 = 9. Wee 19f*4 = 21-2 = 19, so 19d*4 = 12-2 = 10. So 19f*5 = 21-1 = 20, so 19d*5 = 12-1 = 11. So 19f*6 = 21-1 = 20, so 19d*6 = 12-1 = 11. So 19f*7 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d*7 = 12-0 = 20. So 19f-7 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+7 = 12-0 = 13. So 19f-6 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+6 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f-5 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+5 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f-4 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+4 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f-3 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+3 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f-2 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+2 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f-1 = 21-0 = 20, so 19d+1 = 12-0 = 14. So 19f = 21-0 = 20, so 19d = 12-0 = 14. So 19g = 21-0 = 20. So 19h = 21-0 = 20. So 19k = 21-0 = 20. So 19l = 21-0 = 20. So 19m = 21-0 = 20. So 19n = 21-0 = 20. So 19p = 21-0 = 20. So 19q = 21-0 = 20. So 19r = 21-0 = 20. So 19s = 21-0 = 20. So 19t = 21-0 = 20. So 19u = 21-0 = 20. So 19v = 21-0 = 20. So 19w = 21-0 = 20. So 19x = 21-0 = 20. So 19y = 21-0 = 20. So 19z = 21-0 = 20. So 4-0 = 21, so 9+0 = 19;  % In words: 4m = January, 9m = February, 7m = March, 21m = April, 3m = May, 2m = June, 7m = July, 19m = August, 5m = September, 2m = October, 8m = November, 2m = December. Reducing the calendar to 4m from now (so 4m = January, 9m = February, 7m = March, 21m = April, 3m = May, 2m = June, 7m = July, 19m = August, 5m = September, 2m = October, 8m = November, 2m = December. Green rule is \over 2 hours each day. Produces: 4m = January, 9m = February, 7m = March, 21m = April, 3m = May, 2m = June, 7m = July, 19m = August, 5m = September, 2m = October, 8m = November, 2m = December. Blue rules are \over 1 hour each day. Demands: 1/7 for 5 hours from 9m to 5m, 1/3 for 5 hours from 5m to 9m. Daily rest from 5m to 5u. Daily rest from 5u to 20m. Daily rest from 20m to 4m. Daily closing times from 9m to 5m. %20 of rest in 4m, 20 of rest in 9m. Daily starts from 6am. Zero based. Preceding rules: 6m = full moon, 1m = new moon. Green rule is \over 4 hours each day. This corresponds to 2-7 = 3:3 hours per day. Creating 'floating' calendar days, i.e. no time is out of date except by the rotation itself. Each day is to be labeled with a \texttt{weekday} month number, e.g. 1 = January, 2 = February, 3 = March, etc. 2x months are January and February. Produces: 1x = January, 2x = February, 3x = March, etc. 6x months are July. 3x = August. Green rule is \over 2 hours each day. Daily rest from 9m to 1m. Daily rest from 1m to 7m. Daily closing times from 7m to 9m. 15 minutes from 1m to 7m. Some form of mystifying combination rule with at least 6 parts. Each day is to be labeled with one of the above 6 parts, e.g. 22 = July 22, so 33 = July 33, 11 = July 11, 33 = July 33, etc. 2x months are July. 9x = September. Green rule is \over 2 hours each day. Daily rest from 7m to 9m. 15 minutes from 9m to 7m. Daily closing times from 7m to 9m. 3x = October. Green rule is a combination of 2x months, i.e. 2x = October, 2x = November, 2x = December. Daily rest from 7m to 9m. Daily rest from 9m to 3m. Daily closing times from 3m to 9m. 15 minutes from 3m to 9m. Some form of mystifying combination rule. Each day is to be labeled with one of the above 6 parts, e.g. 1x = October 1x = November 1x = December 1x = January. 2x months are November. 9x = September. Green rule is a combination of 2x + 1x months, i.e. 2x = September + 1x, 2x = October + January, 2x = November + February, 2x = December + May. Daily rest from 9m to 1m. 15 minutes from 1m to 9m. \.{center} = \rule{2cm}{2cm} and so on, centre, so on.  % For a bit of extra vertical space,
% the circles can be fitted in a single 2cm wide line
% by using a calc library page layout fit:
\usepackage[margin=2cm]{geometry} % Page settings
\usepackage{lmodern}            % Typeface
\usepackage{tikz}               % Graphic drawing
\usetikzlibrary{positioning}      % Room for coordinates
\usetikzlibrary{backgrounds}    % For graphics fit
\newcommand{\pics}{%
  \def\Center{2,2}%
  \foreach \Angle/\Num in {%
    60/2,
    30/1,
    120/3}%
  {
    \begin{tikzpicture}[
      font=\small\sffamily,
      transform shape,
      % For construction lines
      every node/.style={draw=gray!30},
      % For parameters of lines
      point/.style={coordinate},
      % For circles
      circle/.style={circle, draw, thick,
        minimum size=2*\Radius,
        node contents={}},
      % For rectangles and edges
      rectangle/.style={
        draw = red!30,
        thick,
        fill = red!30,
        rounded corners,
        minimum height=2*\Radius,
        minimum width=2*\Radius,
        font=\small\sffamily,
        text width=1.5cm,  % Read from pic 2
        rotate=\Angle,
        % For node contents
        node contents={},
      },
      border/.style={ultra thick, draw=blue!50} 
    ]
    % Parameters of \pic
    \pgfmathsetmacro{\Radius}{2} 
    \def\Center{\Center} 
    % Nodes of pics
    \node (Center) at (\Center) {};
    \foreach \Ang/\Numb/\Pos in \Numb
    % Nodes of second part of pics
    \node (Ang\Ang/\Numb/\Pos) at ({\Center + (\Ang:\Radius)})
    {\Numb}; 
    % Lines
    \begin{scope}[transform shape]
      \path[draw, border]
      (Ang\Ang1/1/left) -- 
      (Ang\Ang2/1/below left) --
      (Ang\Ang2/2/below right) -- 
      (Ang\Ang1/2/above right) --
      (Ang\Ang1/1/right) -- 
      (Ang\Ang2/1/above left) --
      (Ang\Ang2/\Numb/above left) -- 
      (Ang\Ang2/\Numb/below left) --
      (Ang\Ang2/\Numb/above right) -- 
      (Ang\Ang2/below right) --
      (Ang\Ang/\Numb/above right) -- 
      (Ang\Ang/\Numb/below right) --
      (Ang\Ang/\Numb/below left) --
      (Ang\Ang1/2/below left) --
      (Ang\Ang1/1/below left) -- cycle;
    \end{scope}
    % Defining and adding secondary lines
    % Defining a scope to avoid its double from being drawn
    % and to avoid clipping from being applied on pictures
    \begin{scope}[blend mode=soft light,
      every node/.style={text=gray!30}]
      \path  (-\Center)  node[rectangle] (A) {A};
      \path  (\Center)  node[rectangle] (B) {B};
      \path  (Center)  node[rectangle] (C) {C};
      \foreach \Ang/\Numb/\Pos in \Numb
      % Nodes of second part of pics
      \path (-\Center) node[point] (D-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos) at
      ({\Center} |- C.center) {};
      \path (\Center)  node[point] (E-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos) at
      ({\Center} -| C.center) {};
      % Lines of second part of pics
      \path[draw, red, border]
      (D-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos) edge[bend right] (E-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos)
      (Ang\Ang/\Numb/above left) edge[bend left] (D-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos)
      (Ang\Ang/\Numb/below left) edge[bend right] (E-\Ang-\Numb-\Pos)
    \end{scope}
    % Adding shading to secondary lines
    (-\Center)  node[rectangle, gray!30, opacity=.5,
        path fading=south, fit fading=false]
    (a) {Secundum};
    (\Center)  node[rectangle, gray!30, opacity=.5,
        path fading=south, fit fading=false]
    (b) {Secundum};
    \end{tikzpicture}
  }
  % For shortening some lines
  % Added two of them
  \path (Ang\Ang1/1/below) edge[shorten <=3mm, shorten >=3mm]
  ([shift={(-1mm,-1mm)}]Ang\Ang1/1/below) 
  ([shift={(-1mm,1mm)}]Ang\Ang1/1/below) edge[shorten <=3mm,
  shorten >=3mm] (Ang\Ang1/1/below);
\end{tikzpicture}
}% End of \Center
\end{document}

%                   \basiseval 1 is 1 in mathematical terms.
%                   In other words, it is the '1' symbol
%                   that can be used to represent numbers in mathematical symbols,
%                   for example 3 instead of  3 or 4 instead of 4.5. 
%                   It also includes a built-in calculator that does not need
%                   any external device.
%                   The symbols have a special symbol collection, 
%                   a set of symbols called the'Slavis '. These are
%                   Slavic symbols, and must be collected in a special way.
%                   For every 5 they add up to 1, and when you add
%                   a new one, you are awarded twice the normal
%                   reward (i. e. doubled points or twice the usual
%                   amount of 1's).  This is in addition to the
%                   base points of 5's and 1's that are
%                   accumulated each time a point is collected.
%
%                   There are 8 Slavis symbols in total,
%                   but the number of points that can be
%                   accumulated for each symbol is not fixed. It depends
%                   on the symbol, for example if it is skak or dver,
%                   if it is to be used or not. 
%                   The table below gives the points that
%                   can be accumulated for each symbol,
%                   as well as the symbol that
%                   activates the number of points to be
%                   accumulated. These are the points that
%                   can be awarded for every combination of
%                   symbols/number of lines:

\def\changefont{%
  \expandafter\def\csname pgf@nonlinear@transformation@angle\endcsname{%
    \pgfmathsetmacro\ang{%
      ifthenelse( \pgf@y>0, \the\pgf@y, -\pgf@y) % y to fit the display
      +\pgfmathresult*0.005\pgf@y % the "truncation" (we don't know the height of the page)
      +\pgfmathresult*0.1\textwidth % the "truncation" (we don't know it either)
      +\pgf@y % we need to recalculate the angle
      ifthenelse( \pgf@y<0, -\pgf@y, -\pgf@y-\pgf@y) % y to fit the display
    }
  }%
}

% Define  a counter for counting the number of changed dates.
% The new date is stored in \newdate.
% The counters are used in two separate \documentclasss
% (one for the footer and another for the header) so the counters
% must be decreed in one of these classs or none at all.
\newcounter{newdate}
\newcounter{daycnt}
\newcounter{monthcnt}

% A counter for counting changed months.
% If \newcnt is incremented by 1 only at the beginning
% of the year (as in \mdfysyslibdefinemonth) the entry
% is copied to \newdate.
\newcounter{mntcount}

% The counters must be decreed after the user enters
% the new date. That is done in \yearupdate.
% The counters are decreed on day 1 of the month.
% This is because the counters are increased on the previous calendar day.
\newcommand{\yearupdate}[1]
{%
  \setcounter{daycnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{monthcnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \setcounter{newdate}{0}%
  \setcounter{daycnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \setcounter{monthcnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \ifnum \value{monthcnt} < \value{newdate}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{daycnt} < \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{daycnt}{0}}%
  % Each entry starts from the first second after the user
  % enters the new date. This is why the counters are decreed
  % second by second.
  \ifnum \value{newdate} < \year-\yearupdatey
  {   \setcounter{newdate}{\value{year-\yearupdatey}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{daycnt}\endcsname{0}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{monthcnt}\endcsname{0}%
  \setcounter{daycnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{monthcnt}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{newdate}\endcsname{0}%
  }% 
  \ifnum \value{daycnt} < \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{daycnt}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{mntcount} < \value{newdate}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{monthcnt} < \value{newdate}
  {   \setcounter{monthcnt}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{year} > \yearupdatey
  {   \setcounter{year}{\value{year}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{monthcnt}\endcsname{\csname year\value{monthcnt}\endcsname}%
  }%
  \fi
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{newdate} > \year-\yearupdatey
  {   \setcounter{newdate}{\value{year-\yearupdatey}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{newdate}\endcsname{0}}%
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{newdate} > \year-quicky
  {   \setcounter{newdate}{\year-quicky}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{newdate}\endcsname{0}}%
  \fi
  % Each entry is a fraction of the current year.
  \ifnum \value{year} > 0
  {   \setcounter{year}{\value{year}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname{\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname}%
  \ifnum \value{year} < \year
  {   \setcounter{year}{\value{year}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname{\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname}%
  }%
  \fi
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{newdate} > \year-quicky
  {   \setcounter{newdate}{\year-quicky}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{newdate}\endcsname{0}}%
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{newdate} > \year-quicky
  {   \setcounter{newdate}{\year-quicky}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname value\value{newdate}\endcsname{0}}%
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{year} > \year-quicky
  {   \setcounter{year}{\year-quicky}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname{\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname}%
  }%
  \fi
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \setcounter{mntcount}{0}%
  \ifnum \value{daycnt} > \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{daycnt} > \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{monthcnt} > \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{year} > \value{quicky}
  {   \setcounter{year}{\value{quicky}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname{\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname}%
  \setcounter{year}{\value{quicky}}%
  \ifnum \value{year} > \year-quicky
  {   \setcounter{year}{\value{year}}%
  \global\expandafter\def\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname{\csname year\value{newdate}\endcsname}%
  }%
  \fi
  \ifnum \value{daycnt} > \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%
  \ifnum \value{monthcnt} > \value{mntcount}
  {   \setcounter{mntcount}{0}}%

% labels, and in this case even the counters
% in particular, the counter for the second column
% (i.e. value of the cells content) can be used
% together with the fact that that the counter value
% is shown as whole numbers and not as fractions
% in the case of the Q and A columns
% 
% For example, if the value is 5.5, the final result will be:
%  5.5
%  = 21.0
%  = 10.7
%  = 1.0
%  = 0.0
%
% that the above numbers are not printed in fractions
% but as regular text
%
% Once the layout is defined, specifying the counter format is easy:
%  font = <any font you like> 
%  prefix = <prefix you like>
%  number = <number you like>
%  function = <function that you like>
%  period = <period you like>    
%  units = <units you like to use>
%  function to display the number in given by the counter
%  
% for example, if the value is 5.5, the displayed number will be:    
% 5.5
%  =  21.0
%  = 10.7
%  =  1.0
%  =  0.0
%
% that the above numbers are not printed in fractions
% but as regular text
%
% Last but not least, changing the values period, units and function to be
% in fractions of the original values may be done in the last line of the file
%  font = <font that you like> 
%  prefix = <prefix> 
%  number = <number> 
%  function to display the number in given by the counter
% 
% for example, if the value is 5.5, the displayed number will be:    
% 5.5
%  =  21.0
%  = 10.7
%  =  1.0
%  =  0.0
\ counters % columns to put the data in
:+[
  column/width = 9em, % or any other width you like
  row/.style={columns={0.01 noolor}},
  data/.style={ % or any other style you like
    column/align=left,
    every node/.style={ % or any other style you like
      text width = {width("21.0")},
      align = left, % or any other align you like
      minimum height = 2.2em, 
      font={\scriptsize}
    }
  ]   % columns per row
:+[
  column = 1,
  row = grid
]  % columns between rows
:+[
  column = data,
  row = data,
  count = A
]  % columns between rows
:+[
  column = 1,
  row = grid
]  % columns between rows
:+[
  column = 1,
  row = data,
  count = Q
]  % columns between rows
:+[
  column = 1,
  row = data, 
  count =  % columns between rows
     transform = 1.0 -> 1.0,
   point = A,
   function = display% function to display the number in given by the counter
]   % columns to put the data in

,”>” file icon missing” by converting.pdf Feb 14th, updated March 10th">, and also comes with a CD-Rom file that has 500+ disks. You can ignore the files and data in the.dat and just look at the layout. The.dat format is not a native file format and you will not find any documentation on how to read and write from it. Conversion to and from.pdf is not an issue as you can use pdflatex and xcolor, for example. pdf2ps2pdf can convert to DVI and PS types for latex. You could do a complete redefinition of the user interface in pdf to PS, for example."> You can find out more in the documentation: 2.52 PDFTeX Conversion Manual (PDF 2.52) 2.54 Advanced PDF Features (PDF 2.54) 2.56 The PGF and PGFplots Reference Manual (PDF 2.56) 2.58 The TikZ and PGF Reference Manual (PDF 2.58) 2.60 with pdflatex 3.00 The PGF and PGFplots Reference Manual (PDF 3.00) 3.02 PDF 3.02 is born (PDF 3.02)...">. Conversion to and from.pdf is a perfect use case for pdf2ps2pdf, as it allows you to produce from DVI and PS files. pdflatex is part of the system package and you have to have it on the path, for example, in your.command file:!/usr/bin/systemctl install -f -_daemon 5.04:10 -label=5.04:10 -name=5.04:10 pdflatex.exe! "pdflatex requires xcolor, and is thereforehalted if the color settings are disabled.\nudge down and right by 2.0pt\nudge up and left by 2.0pt"!LaTeX[plainpages=false,hyperindex,colorlinks=true,linkcolor=darkblue,citecolor=darkgreen,urlcolor=blue]{hyperref} PDF 2.04\LaTeX.pdf is born.">. You can ignore that part and just look at the result for your purpose: a PDF user interface.

    \path  (tmp.center) edge [line,red,bend left=-5]  (L);
    % you have other markers defined with posistions, you may want to

    \scope[overlay]
      \path[clip] (O)  edge [line,red,bend left=-25]  (tmp.center);
      \fill[red!100!black] (O)  edge [line,red,bend left=-25]  (tmp.center) circle(.5);
    \endscope
\end{tikzpicture}

% Style the cell to be a rectangle
% The coordinates are for easy translation; use the absolute option
% to avoid stretch and shear (distort) the image

\begin{tikzpicture}
\fill[blue!50!red!75] (-3,-3) rectangle (3,3);
% Add some sun in the south west
\fill[yellow] (current bounding box.south west) ++(0.5,0.5) circle (1);
% Draw a frame around the whole diagram
\draw[white] (-3,-3) rectangle (3,3);
% Use clip to ensure that the red border around the sun is really necessary
% The only part of the diagram that need to be red is the border, inside
% the border is a mirror of the sky, so it should not be red there.
\clip[clip] (-3,-3) rectangle (3,3);
% The diagonals are just drawn to look nice and to demonstrate
% the scaling effect. They are not really necessary.
% you can redraw them in a different way that suits you.
% The green vertical lines are drawn in two parts so that part of the
% image is redrawn on each line redrawn.
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,->] (-3,-3) -- (0,-3);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,<-] (0,-3) -- (3,-3);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,->] (3,-3) -- (3,0);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,<-] (3,0) -- (3,3);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,->] (3,3) -- (0,3);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,<-] (0,3) -- (-3,3);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,->] (-3,3) -- (-3,0);
\draw[line width=3,green!50!black,<-] (-3,0) -- (-3,-3);
% Diagonal dotted lines used to demonstrate scaling
% The line starts at the top left corner of the whole diagram and
% traces its path backwards, bottom up.
\draw[thick,red!75!blue,dotted] (3,3) -- (-3,-3);
% A similar effect can be achieved by reversing the direction of the lines,

% Thus, the sky is shaded with a shaded gradient that starts with a

% sky. The white border is simply drawn as a rectangle combined with the border

Double arc aeguill is a traditional sign that means one thing: to tell time. It is not a calendar, that happens every year on the 1st of January. No, it is not a flower but a sign that we are looking after our planet, and that we are making the most of the things that make it unique. So we decorate. We make the Earth day, we make the double arc aeguill blue every year, we decorate with messages that last a month, every day, in the present and the future, of the calendar year. We make of this change, of this joy, of this hope, of this anxiety, of this uncertainty, this???, a reminder of what is important and a call to all of us to work for the common good. A small reminder, of the things that matter. A reminder to act now, so that we can all be present on the 20th of June, on the birthday of the planet. We bring to the fore things that matter, things that are close to our heart, that make us feel good inside. We change our planet, we make of it a better place, to receive the changes of the year. We love our planet, we protect it, for our children and for ours. A reminder to love, to protect, to preserve, this moment in time.]] --ENDS

\ okay-sitting, even if you are not looking at it, and you have no need for all the extra spaces added for formatting. This is one you need to become very used to look at, and one you may end up loathing looking at if you are used to something else. This is the lucky seat in the graveyard, and its primary function is to collect together all the lost causes to be considered by the whole assembly, and put them in the urn. The lot is a representation of the assembly, and its author is the poet. So if the lot changes, so too does the poet. So if you vote to move a cause from one column to another, or a day to the next, the poet will change also, because he or she is representing that day and that cause. So if you change the font size, or the color of the lot, you change the poet also. The quick time feature can change the font color if the current font is smaller, but the urn is a fixed size. So it must be changed to match the background, and the color must be selected to match that. The color of the day is chosen for its appearance in the urn, so the lot needs to have a background that is in the future, so to match the background of the urn. The color must also match the background of the lot if the urn is to be made of other material than the usual sand. It is not however necessary to get the colors of the day directly from the quick time display, as the lot is set in term of color. Redefine the quick time display to show the lot, rather than its content, so that it too is made to match the urn. The result is added to the current color, so that a yellow background for red is shown in green. The display is therefore a 24 hour circle split into four quadrants of equal area, one red and three green. Daily updates are added to each quadrant from the previous day, so that what is shown in the upper left corner changes if there is a red hour, just as what is shown at the lower right corner changes if there is a yellow hour. Some of the other colors seen in the quick time display are added to the color of the urn in a two part time deal, the hours of the day being separated by a dash or empty space. So if the current hour is 8, for example, you add hours of the day in other colors, blue for the dash of the 8 hour, depending on the current color of the hour, blue for the rest of the day. Part of the display is a 30 day countdown that is reset every day at the beginning of the day, the days of the week added in the top left corner of the urn. A full moon is added at the beginning of the month, the top left corner of the urn updated to represent that, the colors of the day added from the current colors, if the current color is gray, light gray for the moon, if the current color is black, red for the top left corner. A full moon is added at the end of the month, the urn top corner updated, the colors of the day added in the top right corner from the current colors, if the current color is light gray, dark blue for the top right corner. So if you add the moon in two colors, light blue and dark blue, you can vary the top left corner with two colors, light blue or dark blue, depending on the moon, from what you read on the net. The net of the net says a full moon is drawn from the current color, light blue for the top left corner, if the current color is blue, light blue for the top left corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom left corner, the colors of the day added from the current colors, if the current color is light blue, light blue for the bottom left corner. A partial moon is drawn if there is a red hour, red for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom right corner, if the current color is red, red for the bottom right corner, so to render appropriate to the urn. The current color is used, if the current color is light blue, light green for the top right corner, if the current color is blue, blue for the top right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. A gray moon is drawn if the current color is gray, light gray for the top right corner, gray for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. A partial moon is drawn if the current color is red, light red for the top right corner, red for the top right corner, red for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. The current color is used, if the current color is red, red for the top right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. A yellow hour is drawn if the current color is yellow, light yellow for the top right corner, yellow for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. The current color is used, if the current color is light blue, light green for the bottom left corner, light blue for the bottom left corner, light blue for the top left corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom left corner. A black hour is drawn if the current color is black, dark blue for the top left corner, dark blue for the bottom left corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top left corner. A partial black is drawn if the current color is black, dark blue for the top left corner, dark blue for the bottom left corner, black for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom left corner. A gray hour is drawn if the current color is light blue, light gray for the bottom left corner, light gray for the top left corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom left corner. A red hour is drawn if the current color is red, red for the bottom right corner, red for the top right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the bottom right corner. So if the current color is yellow, you yellow for the bottom right corner, yellow for the top right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top right corner. The quick time feature is a real deal, so to render the correct result in the display you need to be shited from the current color, gray for the most part, to white for the other parts. So if the current color is green for the day, you need to use a green for the quick time display, and if the current color is light blue, you need to use a light blue for the quick time display. A partial green is drawn if the current color is green, light green for the top left corner, light green for the bottom left corner, light green for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top left corner. A partial green is drawn if the current color is light red, light green for the top left corner, light green for the bottom left corner, light green for the bottom right corner, so you only need to worry about what you add in the top left corner. \documentclass[tikz,border=5]{standalone}
\usetikzlibrary{arrows.meta,shapes,positioning}
\renewcommand\familydefault\sfdefault
\tikzset{
  arrow/.style = {thick,->,>=stealth}, 
  arrowstart/.style = {minimum width=6mm,inner sep=0},
  arrowend/.style   = {minimum width=6mm,outer sep=0}, 
  sshapes/.style = {draw=blue!50!cyan, fill=blue!50!cyan!20,
                   rectangle, rounded corners, minimum height=6mm, minimum width=6mm},
}
\newcommand\slantbox[2][1]{%
  \parbox[t]{5cm}{\mbox{%
    \ifx\slantbox#1\else #1\fi
    \mbox{%
    \ifx\rlap\SLANTAP\rlap\else \SLANTAP\fi
    }}}
\def\SLANTAP{\mbox{}} % in case the box contains no text
\newcommand\slant[2][]{\mbox{%
  \slantbox[\textwidth]{\mbox{\usebox{#2}}}}}

\newcommand{\replacebox}[4]{%
  \gdef\temp{#4}%
  \foreach \marg [count=\mi from 1] in {#4} {%
    \global\let\finalmarg\marg
    \gdef\temp{\noexpand\node[sshapes,fill=none] at (\mi*6mm,-\mi*6mm) {\usebox{#2}};}%
    \global\let\finalmarg\marg
  }%
  \temp
  \nolinebreak
  \finalmarg
}
\newsavebox\tempbox
\newcommand{\smash}[1]{%
    \sbox\tempbox{$#1$}%
    \smash{%
      \rlap{%
        \kern0pt
        \lower\dimexpr.5em-\ht\tempbox
        \vbox{%
          \hbox{%
            \kern0pt
            \lower\dimexpr.5em-\ht\tempbox
            \vbox to\ht\tempbox{%
              \vss
              \onelineskip=0pt
              \lineskip=0pt
              \topskip\lineskip
              \vbox to\dp\tempbox{%
                \vss
                \newline
                \onelineskip=0pt
                \lineskip=0pt
                \vbox{%
                  \hbox{#1}%
                  \vss
                  \hbox{#1}%
                }%
              }%
            }%
          }%
          \hbox{\usebox\tempbox}%
        }%
      }%
    }%
  }%
}

\.{red},bd,1.75}, you\:{red}, man diagram, 1.5} by Emmace shade, after glass=orange glass. Do not tell me to paint that! :-). I just want to draw the front and back of the box and the space in between. Thanks for the opportunity to use different colors and shades. Emmace shade is new on my vocabulary. I find it hard to think in shades and colors of different sizes. But the box is small so I need to use big enough shades. 1.75x1.5 is the dimensions of the box. So the colors are to be large enough to cover that much square footage. Any smaller coverage and I would need to repeat a lot of the glass. This is why I like working with digital art as it takes up no space and I can print it in the exact size.  I do print my glass so that the front and back of the glass are on the same side of the box. This way I can design so as to make the box a little bigger than the glass. In addition to that I want the whole figure to appear to be on the inside of the box, so I use a double copy path. And of course I want the glass to appear in the front of the box, so I use a path that does not go over the top of the glass. The path in the back is simply the path in the front with the transformation canvas option flipped horizontally and vertically. paths/-8x8/fruits map

\Consumable, and that’s for which you get points for no matter what you do. You get no material cost (that is the deal) and you can really get away with investing in just a couple of counters. So if you ever had to actually work out a solution to a puzzle you were given in terms of numbers and colors, you can still use the counters to make your solution impreative. Now when talking numbers you need to think in terms of two different quantities that balance out to 2. No material is needed for this solution either, and in the case of the counters there is no need to calculate the 1 : 1 between the counters. You can simply move and stack the counters as you please. You will get the impression that you need to do more work than actually doing it. So when you actually think in total of the counters you have worked and of the solutions you have found necessary, you can use the counters again to make your solution prettier. So you will need only blue and red, and you will get the impression that you had to do more work than actually doing it. Red is for the combination of the two counters, and blue is to give the impression that you need to calculate something that is not really there. So while you are calculating something that is really there, you can use the counters for a different purpose. You could calculate 3 from 1 and 2 from 1 or 2 and 3 from 1 or 2 and 3. In total, you need only 1, 2 and 3.. And since when you think in terms of 1, 2, and 3 you can actually think in any combination of three, you will not only forget about the 1-3-2 but also about the 2-3-1 and the 1-2-3. And since there is no 1-3-0 and no 2-3-0 and no 1-2-0, so you could go around in any quantity and colors you like. stack2

% the 14-day cycle is based on 28 total days,
% each day containing 7 being a blue day (so a total of 14 days again)
% starting from day 0 (Sunday)
% the amount of blue days depends on the number of days being a factor
% of 7 (so a total of 28 days again) on the first starting day of the
% cycle. This means that a blue day on Monday is really a blue day
% of 2 days. This also means that a blue day on the 2nd of
% a calendar day is really a blue day on the 3rd of the following calendar
% day. 
% The good part is that each day contains 7 factors of 8+ hours (so a
% day from zero to maximum 7). What the blue days do then, is to do 7
% changes of the day taking factor (so from 0 to maximum 7) and then
% to print a number given in blue days, using the day of the
% current day (so a kind of a counter) and the 7 factor in a bar
% style grid. 
    % The grid and column design is done in a simple way using
    % the TikZ style filters. 
    % The only thing that changes are the values in the column
    % and in the grid style. What changes in the grid is done
    % in a rather simple way. The columns are modified and the grid is changed
    % in a pattern filtering the colours. What is changed in the
    % grid over time is the value in the cell, with the 7 factor
    % being the percentage change and thus the colour. The colours are
    % read from the file conimg/. The filter removes the image and
    % what is left in the colour space is used to define the colour 
    % and in a very simple one where the value in the column is converted
    % to 100 of the colour's value (if it is a simple 3 cell display 
    % colour then it would be).  
    % The file color filter is given two filters:
    % 1. The negation of the given color (this is given twice in the
    % 2. The given colour is 100% of the original color (so if the
    % input color is green the output color will be 100 of that color)
    %   
    % In the last case this means that the filter takes two filters
    % to take into account the negation of the original colour and
    % the fact that the new colour is 100 of that original colour
    % 
    % So the displayed number is really the sum of the numbers of
    % these 3 values and not 3 times the original value
    % 
    % The initial background colour is then set using the
    % initial value in the pattern filter and the 7 factor in the
    % grid style file.
    % The last step is to draw the border. This is done in a way
    % that the columns are drawn on top of the grid, so that part
    % of the border. 
    % There are unfortunately some issues with the positioning so
    % this part has to be adapted. What it does is to make the
    % grid a bit higher, so it has to be smaller or the positioning modified
    % to avoid problems. One part of it that is to remain constant
    % is in the grid style where the style is modified from the initial
    % definition above using a sort of a fairy godmother. What is
    % changed in the grid is the order of the elements and thus where
    % the border is drawn. So the upper part is drawn first and the
    % lower part last. What is changed in the grid is the position of
    % the elements and thus in the size of the elements as a whole
    % and not in the absolute coordinates, so a sort of a rescaling
    % is needed. This is done using simple math and the "round" option
    % (so one is changed from (e.g. \textcolor{magenta}{.9} to
    % .9 and not.9 \color{magenta} ). This is modified in
    % a way that the lower part is drawn when the upper part is drawn
    % in a sort of a cale of hours. If you have a column of hours,
    % one can calculate a column of "seconds" (the math and
    % number format does not allow squares of negative values so a
    % square with zero is added and in a way that is readable and
    % not so much in the absolute coordinates as in the columns
    % and thus after the columns calculation. This is done using
    % a sort of a "text feature" that changes in real time if
    % the columns are changed (you can't just write 1 or 2 hours as text
    % and what is written in the columns is not in the absolute coordinates

    % written in the columns is modified in a way that the result is
    % in the same way as the above definition above for the lines. 
    %

\={2},\in=0.5\relax,  % first second third fourth
    % in=0 out=1, just like in= or out=, but for some reason
    % the second half of the year is considered better than the first,
    % so the in-out rule is used instead
    text width = 12em,  % set the font size to a number that suits you (probably 12 or 13)
    % the rest, like the menu, can be either in-out or in= or out=,
    % and all text is to be centered
    % font = is used to create a typewriter font with bold characters,
    % used in the example here for the first half of the year
    text = font,  % the text is in the text area
    % the borders are added as special nodes, which has the effect
    % that they are underlaid over the text they are added to
    border,color=black,
    boxaround,     % this is used to mark the borders of the
    % content, so that a user can't type in a piece of text and then
    % change the border around it. A nice feature of the boxaround node
    % is that it has the width of two regular nodes, so you can use it
    % to typeset text that is to be the width of a whole column or row
    % In total three boxes are used here, because two of them are identical,
    % but differ in their content
    backgroundcolor=black!10, % a nice trick found in some examples
    bordercolor=black,       % and the other one is to add just under-
    text=white,
    shading = axis,           % a shading that goes from transparent to
    % somewhat opaque, and is used here by double, as he says in the
    % example, so that one can't see through the boxes and can't read
    % the text inside
    backgroundcolor=black!30,
    % double = changes the style of the text inside the node, and thus
    % how it looks, but also makes it wider, because the default font of
    % double is to be 2\linewidth,
    foregroundcolor=black,       % and here again we use the fact that
    % the font can be changed to adjust the size of the text
    borderrotate=90,        % turns the border edges 90 degrees so that
    % they don't coincide with the text
    % node name prefixes: just to save a few typing we use
    % the prefixes defined in the first image
    rowcolor=black!10,       % we need this, because in the example
    % no more space is available than with tabularf and table, so
    % we have to use rows instead of columns
    % colback = black!30 means that the background color is black, but
    % lighter than black!10, so it doesn't overpaints the other
    % boxes and thus doesn't hide part of the text below it
    rowsep = 2mm,            % the extra space added between rows
    columnsep = 2mm,        % the extra space added between columns
    % and it is this that gives the different effect to each of the
    % boxes
    % whereborder = means that the border around the node is drawn as
    % if the node was around a certain point, instead of being drawn as
    % a square with corners as if it was a border around a real box
    borderstyle = {draw=black},
    % ulem : to add some special options to the above nodes
    ulem = {ultra thick},
    % now you have a box around the main box, and inside that main box
    % there is a wider box
\parindent = 0em
\kern-1em
\sbox0{\rule{12em}{2em}}% the sizing is performed relative to the text in the node
\sbox1{\rule{12em}{2em}}% and the format is like in the example,
% so that half of the year 0 is given by the + sign, and the other half
% in the - sign
\sbox2{\phantom{\rule{12em}{2em}}}% in the example
  \unskip\unskip% in total three boxes, and three separate images,
% but the idea is the same: typeset the text in a node, and go to the
% line between the nodes with the double command
\sbox3{\phantom{\rule{12em}{2em}}}% there is no image here, so no box
\begin{document}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[
  pics/myimage/.style={code={%
    \tikzset{My Image/.style={rounded corners = 2mm, text = black, 
      font=\fontsize{52}{52}\selectfont, text width = 24em, align=left}}}
  ] 
    % the box below is typeset in the style My Image, and thus has the
    % correct size for the text below the x-axis, although it is center
    % aligned by default
    \node [
      My Image, 
      minimum height = \ht2, % height of the top box
      minimum width = \wd2,  % width of the right box
      anchor=north west
    ]  (lower) {Lower \\ \raisebox{\dimexpr 1.5\ht2-2\ht3\relax}{% 1.5 height of top box
      \raisebox{-\dimexpr 2\ht3-\ht2\relax}{\textcolor{blue}{\textbf{lower}}}};};

    % the top box is typeset in the style My Image, and thus has the
    % correct size for the content, which is typeset in the next picture
    % (compare this image with the one from the right box in the example)
    \node [
      My Image, anchor = north
    ] (upper) at (lower.south){\raisebox{\dimexpr \ht2-2\ht3\relax}{%
        \textcolor{red}{\textbf{up}}}};
    % the upper box is typeset in the style My Image, and thus has the
    % correct size for the content, which is typeset in the next picture
    % (compare this image with the one from the left box in the example)
    \node [
      My Image, anchor = west
    ] (left) at (upper.east)(leftupper) {\raisebox{\dimexpr \ht2-2\ht3\relax}{%
        \textcolor{green}{\textbf{left}}}};
    % the lower box is typeset in the style My Image, and thus has the
    % correct size for the content, which is typeset in the next picture
    % (compare this image with the one from the right box in the example)
    \node [
      My Image, anchor = south
    ] (lower) at (leftupper.south -| lower.south west){%
        \raisebox{\dimexpr \ht2-2\ht3\relax}{%
        \textcolor{violet}{\textbf{lower}}}};
    % add shadow to the lower box, as requested by daleif in the comments
    % below the example
    \node [circle, draw = black, ultra thick, fill = black!30, minimum size = 8ex,
        right, anchor = east] at (lower.east)(c){};
    \draw [ultra thick, draw=black, -stealth, double] (leftupper) to [bend left = 45] (c.east) 
    to [bend left] (lower);
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{document}

\document[3d,english,roof,color=gray] make -> screen=3d window natural tick. size grid from screen=2 size grid from screen=1 we like to view from top side of grid to show better its contents. window = {rotating, % the more changes are made to the window, the more clearly it is seen. The ‘trangeness’ of the model is used for this. Small changes have to be made to the code to make it work on RoT, this is why we use the PGFPlots package.} options = {ugroupedREET citations, thmmarks, th, th, h, v, comments, minor, minorupdate, 2017-09-01,.} screen -> rgb plane, thenormal axes, meta axes, daryld, grid, grid unit = cm, time map = MAM}
[
  grid=none,  % prevents changes to the grid structure
  opacity=.9,  % makes the colors more opaque
  cell size = 5mm,  % makes all cells the same size regardless of the original opacity
  tick size = 1mm,  % small ticks on all axes, makes for a jarring effect, but also makes the graphs look cluttered
  visualize as line=graph,  % visualizes the given graph as line, using the given.append style for graph
  x=2.25cm, y=2.25cm, z=1.75cm,  % gives a 2.25x2.25x1.75 scale to the model being plotted
  axis background/.style={ fill = blue!50! black!40 }, % partial frame at the top of the model
  x=2cm, y=2cm, z=1.2cm,  % makes the entirety of the grid clearer to view
  y axis line style = { draw opacity = 0 },  % effects and text opacity
  x axis line style = { draw opacity = 0 },  % effects and text opacity
  x tick label style = { text opacity = 0 },  % text opacity is zero after modification
  y tick label style = { text opacity = 0 },  % text opacity is zero after modification
  z tick label style = { text opacity = 0 },  % text opacity is zero after modification
  minor tick num =5,  % makes the minor tick lines more common, and in turn, makes the grid more visible
  major tick num =25,  % makes the major ticks more common, thus making the grid more obvious
  domain=1:30  % makes the plots from 1:30 in both axes
]
rotating environment
lcf ={transform shape} % horizontal controls the rotortions, just like with the 3D goggles
schememap
[
  size = screen = 2:2
]
{
  ftype = visualize as scatter, % needs to be added after the initial sketch
  y filter = screen opacity = 0.95,
  visualization = ncolor,  % makes the colors used by the goggles, they are read as.dat file
  contour
]
  % The data generated by the GIs is lost when the graph is rendered, so
  % we use a data filter to reverse the transformation from contour to
  % color. The transformation is from.dat file to.pdf file, so we need a
  % data filter that preserves the transformation to.dat file. Compare
  % the original transform with this one.
  transform = data point color,
  filter = dat to pdf,
  /tikz/cap=round,
}
} {
  color = gray,
  opacity = 0.75,
  gray line = 1ex,
  stroke color = red,
  text opacity = 1,
  text = transparent,
}
[  
  grid = off,
  axis background = orange!50!red,
  color = blue,
  planet color = cyan,
  bone color = red,
  color = yellow,
  color = green,
  color = teal,
  color = purple,
  color = magenta,
  color = teal,
  color = red,
  time = slant = 1:1,
  3D view = {slant = 0:1},
  slant = 1:1,
  rotate = 180,
]
rotating;
} rotation path
} {
  planet 7,  planet 6, planet 5,
  moon 15, moon 20,  moon 30,
  star 5, star 10, star 15, star 20,
  cometary 11, cometary 12,
}
}

      border=3pt,  % around the image

      ] layout and format in grid 12 is defined. We can do
      3D with this 3D-ship, and use layers to visualize
      3D.  This diagram is not really 3D but more of a 2D
      illustration. The main concept of the diagram is given by
      3D.  You can ignore the "2" and "3" of course, but really
      the combination of colors creates the 3D effect. 2D
      version is in the boxes, you just have to ignore the sizes
      and colors of the boxes.  One of the clever things is that
      3D is not really 3D but more of 2.5D.  In the final
      version, 2.5D is mixed with 3.5D.  That is what gives
      3D to the diagram. The minimal change to visualize 3D
      is in the "before" layer. It is not really necessary because
      3D can be read from the 3D option given in the initial
      3D file.  But the minimal change gives a good impression
      of 3D. 3D is also given by layers.  We can use the layers
      feature to slow down the flow of information and add a
      time element.  This gives us a kind of 3D time travel.
      We can also change the order of the layers, you do not have
      to obey to their order in the file.  But of course, to get
      the 3D effect there is an order. 3D is like a 2 in 2D and you
      need to put it "in front of" 2D. 3D is also like 2D "behind"
      2D.  So if 2D is in front of 3D, 2D is "behind" 3D, and
      if 3D is in front of 2D, 2D is "behind" 3D.  This is
      what the layers concept is all about. It deals with the flow
      of information from 2D to 3D to 2D.  The layers can be
      before, behind, or both. This gives a kind of 3D Fates
      type of effect.  This kind of 3D is not really 3D but more
      of a 2.5D type of 3D.  We can ignore the fates because
      2.5D is like 3.5D.  In 2.5D 3D is more than 3D and less 2.5D.  
      This is why we call 2.5D 3.5D (2.5D meaning 2 plus 0.5D meaning 2.5D) and not 2.5D meaning 2.5D.  This also gives a
      kind of 3D Fates type of effect.  We can ignore the meaning
      of the fates because 2.5D is more than 3D and less 2.5D
      (we can still ignore the meaning). 
      So, the meaning of the fates is ignored and we just go with
      the flow of information. This is what the layers do.  We
      just have to ignore the times the layer is in front of 2D
      (the border of the 3D diagram) and the time of the fates
      (we need to change it when the 3D changes).  The "before" and
      "after" layers are in front of 2D and so we ignore
      them.  We just have to change the order of the layers and
      we are away from 2D.   
      Fig. 3.2 (three dimensional) Space Station 3D (manually 3D)
      visualizer based on the 3D  hyperdocument of David Eberle.  
      It has four main components: Space, Base Station,
      Nave, Shuttle, Abort, Storage. Space is either 2D or
      3D. 2D stands for "2 dimensions" and 3D for "three
      dimensions" (in English: space station). 3D also includes
      three dimensions (3D) but here 3D means "more" 3D
      (3D) than 3D. 3D is more of an attitude (fig. 4) than of a
      geometric figure (fig. 5). 3D is also more of a group of
      elements than of a single element. That is why 3D is
      ambiguous, you can mean 3D or you can mean nothing or you
      can mean a group of things. This is what David Eberle calls
      "hyperdocument" (fig. 6). 3D is like a 2.5D (fig. 7) and so
      we get a double effect. 3D is also like 2.5D "behind" 2.5D
      (fig. 8, fig. 9).  We can ignore the result of 3D in
      these examples but we will get a good impression of 3D
      from the order in which we have to put the fates.  (If you

      Space is an example for 3D (fig. 11).  Space is 3D before

\documentFOLLOW [2017/11/26] the very powerful FOLLOW
module for Drikz [Felix Dominik Wirtus] \grapics about
Mercury's 21-Feb-2017 feature are based on.licensing and
cross-restricting. This is not that obvious in the
licensing sense, and I would have given up if I would have to change
dates or postion of stuff in the page. Using the grapics
format makes it very easy to lay out the text and image
sequently. I just needed to adjust the page sizes. For
Mercury 21-Feb-2017 there is a minimum width set at 4cm,
which also has to be considered in the image position. One
thing I find very strange is the zero point zero just before the
gadgets. This is in sharp contrast to the 3D effect that
is seen in the other two dimensions. So if you are to paint
your way through Mercury, you may have to put up with some
zero points to zero. \r These days I like very much
to have a "current page" link from the status bar in the
top menu. The "current page" is the page where the "current
document" is, i.e. the page where the >title< is located. I
also like to have a bookmarks bar, from where I can jump to
relevant pages and sections. One thing I find
difficult is that the bookmarks bar is in the left margin, so
I mainly use it for bookmarks. I do not use the right
button, because I consider its content "wrong". \r
Overwriting, i. e. changing the properties of existing
elements, is not possible in a \enquote{followed page};
link. So is redrawing. \r

% I prefer not to use png's with a \path in the style,
% but just declareing a variable as png would allow
% to use the \path to draw the diagram. png's are pdf's too,
% but with the current PGF version (3.0) there is no need to
% create them for your diagram. But you may create one for your
% particular diagram. You may want to create a "generic" one,
% and only show the different contents in each particular diagram. \r
\def\pgfpathgeneric#1{
  \begin{tikzpicture}[baseline=(P.base)] % change baseline to your needs
    \tikzset{
      path image/.style={
        transform canvas={xshift=#1,yshift=#1},
        path picture={ % access the graphic contained in the style
          \pgfgetpath\pgfpathimagepath % and save it to \global
          \gdef\pgfpathimagepathglobally{\pgfpathimagepath} % or locally
          \path (\pgfpathimagepath); % navigate to the graphic
          \pgfgetpath\pgfpathimagepathglobally % and locally
          % clear the global path
          \global\let\pgfpathimagepathglobally=\pgfpathimagepath % and locally
        }
      },
      path picture={
        % If the image is a graphic, load it. \pgfpathimagepathglobally
        \ifpdf{ % only for PDF
          \pgfprocesspathextractcoordinates{\pgfpathimagepath}{\cpts) %
          %\global\setlength{\cpx}{\csname pgf@path@length@a\endcsname} %
          % store the coordinates in the \global-environment. No need
          % to download again what I already had in the \cpts)
          \pgfextracty{\cpts}{\pgfpointorigin} %
          % save the current coordinate to \cpts
          \gdef\cpts{\pgfpointorigin}
          % only for the example I just need to save the x,y-coordinates
          % to locally \cpts
          \gdef\localspts{\pgfpointorigin}
        }{
          \gdef\cpts{\pgfpointorigin}
          \gdef\localspts{\pgfpointorigin} % only for the example
        }
        % the image is now in the \pgfpathimagepathglobally
        % environment, access it as \pgfpathimagepathglobally
        \global\let\pgfpathimagepathglobally=\pgfpathimagepath % locally
        % The \pgfpointdiff between the \pgfpointorigin and the
        % saved \pgfpathimagepathglobally coordinates gives us the
        % image width. I had to adapt my grid size to the image width
        \pgfpointdiff{\pgfpointanchor{\pgfpathimagepathglobally}{west}} %
        {\pgfpointanchor{\pgfpathimagepathglobally}{east}} %
        % to get the needed width for the vertical bar
        \global\pgf@xa=\pgf@x % need to locally save the
        % global difference between \pgf@xa and \pgf@x to locally
        % save time when you need it. I made the same change in
        % the example environment
        \gdef\mygridwidth{\the\pgf@xa} % change only the grid width
        % enlarge the grid for the example
        \pgfmathsetlengthmacro\myenlarging{\mygridwidth/2} % enlarge the
        % grid a bit more than half of the computed width
        \pgfmathsetlengthmacro\myenlarging{\mygridwidth/2+0.5}
        % enlarge the smaller horizontal dimension
        \pgfmathsetlengthmacro\myhwidth{\myenlarging}
        % enlarge the other two dimensions
        % create the bar to show the image changes
        \global\advance\cpts by \pgf@xa % only for the example
        \global\advance\localspts at (-\myenlarging,-\myenlarging) % enlarge
        % the left lower corner
        \gdef\myhwidth{\the\pgf@xa}
        % enlarge the other two dimensions
        % in total the bar will be shifted
        \global\advance\cpts at \mygridwidth
        \gdef\mywidth{\the\pgf@xa}
        % the bar
        \global\advance\localspts at (-\mywidth,-\mywidth) % enlarge the
        % left upper corner
        \gdef\myvwidth{\the\pgf@ya} % enlarge the vertical dimension
        \gdef\myvheight{\the\pgf@ya} % enlarge the vertical dimension
        % enlarge the other two dimensions
        % we need only the x-coordinate
        \gdef\myxwidth{\the\pgf@xa} % enlarge the x dimension
        % the other three are global over the diagram and not needed
        \global\advance\cpts by \myhwidth % only for the example
        \global\advance\localspts at (-\myhwidth,-\myhwidth) % enlarge the left

% Font changes

% Defining the length of the horizontal rule
\def\hrulelength{2.5cm}

\def\tablecaption#1{%
    {|-2.5cm|-\scriptsize#1\\-2.5cm|}
    }

% Defining the length of the vertical rule
\def\vruleheight{1.2cm}
\newlength{\vruleheight}
\setlength{\vruleheight}{\vruleheight}
\def\vrule#1{%
    \rule[-2.5cm]{#1}{\vruleheight}%
    \rule[-2.5cm]{2.5cm}{\vruleheight}%
}

% Counting the number of hours in a week
% when working on a deadline
\newcommand\weekcount{14} % e.g. 5 for Monday to Friday
\def\hourwork{7} % e.g. 7 for Monday to Friday
\newcommand\workperiod{24}
% Defining the font for the typeset of hour
\newcommand\hourfont{\sffamily\Huge}

\newcounter{hrtotal}
\newcounter{hrremaining}
\newcommand\hrremaining[2]%
{    \setcounter{hrremaining}{#1}%
    \setcounter{hrtotal}{#2}%
    \advance\hrtotal by -\hrremaining%
    \ifnum\hrtotal=0
        \ifnum\value{hrremaining}=\hrremaining
            \hrulewidth=2pt
            \vruleheight=2pt
            \hrulewidth=0pt
            \vruleheight=0pt
            \hrulewidth=0pt
        \fi
    \fi
}

% Setting up the animation
% if playing more than one hour a day for a total of 24 hours
\multifitnew{hr}
% Counting the number of hours in a day as the animation proceeds
\newcommand\hrcount{0}

\begin{document}
% Creating the animation "in real time"
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{animateinline}[autoplay,loop,
    poster=first,controls={play,play,play}]{10}
\whiledo{\thehrremaining > 0}{
    \hrulewidth=2pt
    \vruleheight=2pt
    \hrulewidth=0pt
    \vruleheight=0pt
    \hrulewidth=0pt
    \advance\hrremaining by -\workperiod
    \stepcounter{hr}
    \ifnum\thehrwork>\workperiod
        % Calculating the new work period
        \pgfmathtruncatemacro{\workperiodnew}{\workperiod-\hourwork}
        \setcounter{hrwork}{\workperiodnew}
    \fi
    \ifnum\hrwork > 0\relax
        % Calculating the new hour work
        \hrcount=\hrwork
        \setcounter{hrcount}{\hrcount}
        \ifnum\hrcount > \hrremaining
            % Working extra hours
            \hrremaining=\hrremaining-\hrwork
            \stepcounter{hrremaining}
        \fi
    \else
        % Working regular work hours
        \setcounter{hrwork}{\hourwork}
    \fi
    \ifnum\hrcount = 0
        \hrrulewidth=0pt
        \vruleheight=0pt
        \hrulewidth=0pt
        \vruleheight=0pt
        \hrrulewidth=2pt
        \vruleheight=2pt
        \hrremaining=0
    \fi
    \ifnum\hrcount > 0\relax
        \hrrulewidth=2pt
        \vruleheight=2pt
        \hrrulewidth=0pt
        \vruleheight=0pt
        \hrrulewidth=0pt
    \fi
    \ifnum\hrcount = \workperiod
        \hrrulewidth=2pt
        \vruleheight=2pt
        \hrrulewidth=0pt
        \vruleheight=0pt
        \hrrulewidth=0pt
    \fi
    % Drawing the hour and the vertical rules
    \hrulewidth=\hrrulelength
    \vruleheight=\vruleheight
    \ifnum\hrcount > -1\relax
        \hrulewidth=0pt
        \vruleheight=\vruleheight
    \fi
    \hrulewidth=\hrrulelength
    \vruleheight=\vruleheight
    \hrremaining=\hrremaining
    \hrremaining=6% if the final hour is on a Monday
    % Drawing the table
    \hrulewidth=5.4cm
    \vruleheight=2pt
    \hrulewidth=2pt

      % page
      % 1:1 switch to the previous page
      % 2:1 switch to the next page
      % (or just 1 if you want to go to the page without
      %  changes in page layout).
      % 21:1 goes to page full of 21 degree angle in the
      %  horizontal plane of the rectangle. It is like saying 21:1
      %  to the user who started from a corner (of the
      %  rectangle). The angle 21 is 21° in the example.
      % 0:0 goes to the page origin (initially the top left corner)
      % 270:1 goes to the page origin (this was mandatory for the
      %  OP).
      \directlua{
        function coor(i,j,n)
          tex.print(string.format(
            "[coordinate[n=%1] %c at (%2), (%3, %4)]",
            i,
            j,
            n,
            ", %c"
          ))
        end
      }
      tex.print(
        string.format(
          "\directlua{ Coor(#1,#2,#3); }",
          #1,#2,#3,
        )
      )
      ) % #1 is x, #2 is y and #3 is direction #4 in degree
      % (0,0) is their initial point. The #4 is from 0 to 360
      % we need to go from #4 to #4-360.
      % If the final point is #4-360 then we use #4-360+1 and so on.
      % This way 0 is always the same no matter what #4 is.
      % This is why we need #4-360+1 at the end.
      -- 0,
      % hence we go from 0 to 0-360.
      cycle
    }
    % Now the final corner is at (0,0) and in  the example
    % #1 is 0
    % #2 is 21
    % #3 is 0-360+1 (horizontal axis of the rectangle)
    % #4 is rotated #4-360+1 clockwise from the initial corner.
    % So #5 is the initial point after rotating #4-360+1.
    % #6 is from #7 (this is the initial point of the counter)
    % #7 is 0-360+1 clockwise from #7.
    % We need #7-360+1 not #7
    -- cycle
    % So #8 is from #9 (at most of the top left corner)
    -- cycle
    % (to final corner of the rectangle)
    21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 0-360+1 21 21 0-360+1 0-360+

\.{circle}\.{egeg\"are};% Proposta per la Costituzione della Repubblica slovena
Ricordando l'indipendenza della Slesia tedesca e della nazione slovena indipendente da Vienna (ustria), la proposta suggerisco di unaCostituzione ristrutturazione della Repubblica secondo un modello federal (4+3) di Piccolia, prospettando un riordino deipotital della Suoprauropa al di contro della Austria e della tedesccia.
* Cfr. Proposta della Presidenza al R. Sabato (17.01.2014)
* Cfr. Proposta del Senato (21.03.2014)
* Cfr. Voto in Sessione (26.04.2014)
